column4: Hi...Can someone tell me how the $PATH variable is set BEFORE the local .bashrc file is called?
why?
because some weird paths are in there everytime a open a new shell. However, these paths do not appear in my .bashrc file, so they have to come from somewhere else.
what kind of weird paths?  Check /etc/environment (I don't think this is used for path though), /etc/bash*, and /etc/profile*
you should say what these "weird paths" you refer to actually are
I don't see any paths in what you said
yes, we understand your problem.  If you give us information we ask about, we can try to help you.
sure, paste the output of « echo $PATH »
pastebin result of « ls ~/.bash* ~/.profile »
pastebin the contents of your ~/.bashrc and ~/.profile
while you do that, when you need to add something to your PATH, what do *you* do?
yes, you have a few additions like that in your .bashrc.  Which part of your PATH exactly are you not sure where it comes from?
most of the things that are in the past before the past gets "filled" by the .bashrc. Especially the path to my "old" eclipse installation
get rid of all these PATH manipulations you have in your .bashrc, and put them in your .profile instead
did this. Now ONLY the old paths are there, the new ones weren't added at all.
what new ones?
the ones i  put in the .profile
pastebin the relevant configuration files, and what your PATH looks like, and what you want it to look like
by the way, you need to log out and back in for .profile to be read.  If you want to just source it for your current shell, you can do « source ~/.profile »
IT WORKS! Ok, I really had to log out from my account! I thought opening another shell or just sourcing the new altered.bashrc file was enough.
Thanks a lot for your time and your help!
no problem.  Basically, that ~/.profile gets executed one time at login, but your .bashrc gets executed at login (because .profile sources it) and also when you open a new shell
didn't know that. Again, thanks again and good night!
